s: Judd Wallenbrock said... Tom -- thanks so much for keeping us all up to date and informed regarding this silly...but very real threat...not only to our industry but to our basic rights as consumers.
Tom Wark said... Scott: Thanks for the tips.

Steve said... Tom: Thanks for this passionate polemic, a foreceful and sorely needed rebuttal to a bogus bill.
Tom said... Seems like some old geezers are filling their pockets with some major greenbacks getting this bill passed through.
r said... Wow!

A lady was walking past a pet store when a parrot said, ''Hey, lady! You're really ugly!"
Why do you require -- why do you say the clause has got to be read by this kind of specific causation theory as opposed to a kind of systemic theory of promotion?
Do you say the same thing for scope?
We have not said that "promote the progress of science" is a general and independent constraint on the Copyright Clause authority.
We've said it must be looked to to interpret the scope of "limited times," and unless retrospective extensions are forbidden, it will eviscerate the meaning of "limited times."
And so let's just take -- let's say that was your only argument in this case.
It seems that you're just saying there that 70 years is an unreasonable -- is not necessary.
Precisely--actually, we're not saying anything about the 70 years in this case even under the First Amendment, because we believe it's unseverable, but --
What I'm saying is not that it's the retrospectivity that makes the First Amendment argument troubling --

All I'm saying is, we have addressed the retrospective portion of CTEA, and so I'm saying in the retrospective portion of CTEA you would apply ordinary, intermediate First Amendment review, and you would ask --

All I'm saying is, we have addressed the retrospective portion of CTEA, and so I'm saying in the retrospective portion of CTEA you would apply ordinary, intermediate First Amendment review, and you would ask --

Well, this Court really has not -- if you say that the Copyright Clause is not violated, I don't think there are examples where this Court has then resorted to First Amendment analysis to invalidate the same act.
We've said there was a general grant, and that Congress was free to run with it in many respects.
In many respects, Mr. Chief Justice, but, as this Court has also said, there are limits to what Congress can do under the Commerce Clause.

As this Court explained 100 and some years ago in its Burrows-Giles opinion, such constructions are accorded very great weight and, as that Court went on to say, when consistent and unchallenged for over a century are almost conclusive that consistent construction by Congress of its authority under the Copyright and Patent Clause now has lasted from the 105th -- from the first through the 105th Congress.
It says the --
Well, I want to say, do you think yes or no?
I hate to say may --
So you think, say, Verdi, Othello, Verdi, Othello, 80 years old, the prospect of an extra 20 years way down the pike would have made a difference?
It is -- well, it -- let me say with respond -- in response to both of those questions, an unlimited time would violate the Copyright Clause.

General Olson, you say that the functional equivalent of an unlimited time would be a violation, but that's precisely the argument that's being made by petitioners here, that a limited time which is extendable is the functionable, functional equivalent of an unlimited time, a limited time that 10 years from now can be extended, and then extended again, and extended again.
I mean, if you say you need 70 years because of changes in the economy to encourage works, you grant 70 for the future, but why does that, making that apply to somebody provided him?

It would be very difficult for the Framers to have eschewed deciding 14 years was a constitutional limitation, and for this Court to say 99 years is, and again, even the petitioners aren't asking the Court to make that judgment.
The petitioners are only saying that there shall be a per se rule that the word "limited times," means unchangeable times.

-- that unless there is a -- the Court is -- because the circumstances change, that we are living in an era now where piracy is a significant problem, there's question of administrative ease, of administering a system where copyrights may be different for one set of authors, or different for another set of authors, there's changes that are taking place internationally, so that what we're saying is that not only could this Court conceive of reasons why Congress thought it was accomplishing the objectives of this clause, but that there are numerous objectives that are entirely legitimate in --
Basically you're saying the presumption ought to be in the congressional judgment about how to draw the line as well as in how long a line to draw.

I mean, that would seem -- where this equity idea is the camel and the production idea is the gnat, and is there any -- can we say something like that, or does Congress have total leeway in respect to --

JACK SPARROW Any idea when Jones might release said terrible beastie?
SHRIMPER Cannot say about Jack Sparrow.
[Jack says nothing, arises from his throne, walks over to Will]
RAGETTI Well I say it was divine providence what escaped us from jail.
